reviews.review_text: Really cute and fun little game. It‘s pretty short as rpg, but you‘ll have a fun time playing it. It‘s simple and pretty easy. You play as the kids, form your party and collect candies and costume parts made of cardborad. When the fight starts you‘re being transformed into your costumes (robot, ninja, knight etc.) and the fight begins. Fight system is generic turn based rpg system but it doesn‘t need to be different. Seriously go and buy it, it‘s really really good game i promise you will fall in love with this little cute gem :)
Be a kid. Collect candy. Save the world. Fun game if you are looking for something short and sweet.

The first time I ever had my eyes on this masterpiece was when Ceildric was streaming this game for the Forum Vaporis's 24hr Halloween stream. I fell in love with this game even if I wasnt the one playing it and when I finally got the game, Boy did it blow me away. If I had to choose one game from Double Fine's roster, This would be the one I'd pick up and play. Its pretty small game time wise but you will enjoy the journey. Its pretty easy to 100% the game too.

Costume Quest has you play as Wren or Reynold, a brother and sister duo who vow to save Hallowe'en from the evil candynapping monsters who have invaded their neighbourhood!  First, let's get it out of the way. This game has no voice acting. At all. It's all ambient sounds and SFX. At first it's weird, but it isn't too bad at all. After 20 minutes you forget your expectations and just accept the design choice.  The game is super fun and exudes charm, with the classic Double Fine level of humour and level design.  I spent 7 hours completing the game 100% including all DLC and achievements, and it was very enjoyable, both in story and gameplay, with perfect controller integration.   I was so 'hooked' by the little questhubs that I actually played the entire game in one sitting, and finished the DLC the day after. Very addictive, very fun.  Highly recommended!  Nilesy

This is probably one of the cutest, most charming games I've played.  The game mechanics aren't anything ground breaking. It's a pretty straight forward RPG battle system where you transform into the literally larger-than-life version of your chosen Halloween costume. But the game's world is what you wanted to experience when you were 10 years old. You wanted to BE your costume (which picking was one of the most important decisions you made all year). You wanted life to be very cartoony. Candy was more precious than money.  The game oozes charm. It has child characters that are actually likable, funny, and clever, which is pretty rare in video games. The monsters and villians are pretty funny. Basically, it's just so fun!

Charmingly cute turn-based RPG. The game has a simple comic-book aesthetic, and is full of silly characters and clever dialogue.   Through the power of the children's imagination, in battle they transform into towering fighters, based on the costume they are currently donning. These fighters include a robot, a ninja, a unicorn, and a giant crab made out of french fries.   The four hub areas feel visually distinct, but the quest types in each zone are very similar. You will find hidden children, bob for apples, knock on doors to 'Trick-or-treat', receiving either a handful of candy or entering into a battle.   The battle system in this game is almost stiflingly simple. Each costume has a basic attack and a special move that can be used every three turns. Attacks and defense are managed through simple quick-time events, and there are no items or resistances to keep track of in battles.  Your parties stats are limited to HP, Attack Power, and Defense. Levelling up increases these stats by a fixed amount. The only character management lies in deciding which costumes to wear, and spending candy to obtain stamps which give various perks in battle. Each character can only equip one stamp at a time, and some are undoubtedly more powerful than others.   Difficulty is very low, especially once you have a full party.

Costume Quest  is a Double Fine RPG set around Halloween where by some magical intervention, your character and his or her friends gain the ability to transform into super powered versions of their costumes to save your sibling who has been mistakenly kidnapped as a result of dressing in a terrible candy costume.  It's very... Double Fine. I really don't know how they make their games all feel so similar despite them having different mechanics and stories and settings. Art and dialogue, I suppose. Anyway, that's my only negative-ish criticism.  It's a pretty good short RPG, with quick time attacks/dodging similar to the Mario RPGs. It is actually reasonably difficult despite how it might look so if you're buying this for kids, consider that. I like the innovation of having 'random encounters' limited to houses where you're trick or treating. The story is kind of sparse, but manages to touch on some themes of the difficulties of siblinghood. It fits into the game's world organically, so I can appreciate that.
This game is one of my favourite games. It's a cute game that I enjoy playing every year during the Halloween, but not only. I could say the game became a tradition for me :D
Even with how short it is, it gets repetitive very quickly. 3 small hub worlds that have you repeating the same mini-games and item hunting tasks over and over with no variation.
sticks and stones may break my bones but NERDS will never hurt me

Let's see... Costume Quest is one of those games that you may only enjoy if you're 13 yo. or younger, or you just have some serious nostalgia going on... I do hate to not recommend this game, but you can probably tell if its for you by looking at the screenshots. Thats about it.
Short but awesome turn based mini rpg that has pretty funny dialogue.
Haven't played for very long, but so far it's pretty fun!

A cute Halloween-themed RPG game with a good story, turn-based combat, a mixture of painted and cel-shaded graphics, and good music (and sound effects in general). Kept me entertained for hours. Well worth the price.

Utterly charming. I grinned like an idiot throughout much of the entire, just-long-enough experience.  Broken down, you and your annoying sibling go off trick-or-treating until suddenly, MONSTERS! When your brother/sister is nabbed, you must retrieve them at all costs.  Set against the backdrop of a neighbourhood on Halloween, you travel across a town battling no-goodniks in a modified turn-based battle system. The powers you have in each fight are determined by the costume you're wearing. Costumes are acquired through standard adventure gameplay, but some cool ones are secret... can you find everything the game has to offer?

Did you play the Penny Arcade games? Because it's almost exactly like that. Tim Schafer basically took the unfinished series and made a new game out of it, only with new IP that's a lot more charming and fun. The gameplay's nothing special but overall it's a good time and worth it at sale price.

This game was a heap of fun! It puts a nice little twist on traditional turn-based RPGs, the story is simple but the dialogue was hilarious, I was cracking up the whole day just couldn't put the controller down!  Speaking of controllers, the main problem with it was how obnoxious the rumble in it is when you play with a controller, and the fact you don't have the option to shut it down. I don't have anything against rumble itself, but it kept disconnecting my controller everytime it rumbled over and over, until finally the other day I was able to make it stop disconnecting my controller, had to use x360ce and such to do that. That's all though, nothing against the game itself can't wait to play the sequel ^^

The Paradox's review on:  Costume Quest   NOTICE: Verdict on bottom of this review.   My quick notes to the devs  Where to start... first, I must say that I got this game by a coupon and stumbled apon it quite randomly.   I MUST   say that this game is   AMAZING!

I love this game! I was looking for something to get me in the mood for Halloween and this was perfect- cute, spooky and full of little details and secrets. There are lots of side-quests and things to collect along the way, which appeals to me a lot. The costumes and battle opening sequences for each costume are really well done. The one thing I struggled with initially was the mechanics during battles; you have to press the specified key at exactly the right time to execute a successful attack or defence which took me a while to get my head around! After a while, though, I found this aspect to be enjoyable and the difficulty curve was just right, I think. All in all I loved playing this, and would definitely recommend to those who like cuteness, collecting things and really well decorated Halloween scenes :)

Did you play the Penny Arcade games? Because it's almost exactly like that. Tim Schafer basically took the unfinished series and made a new game out of it, only with new IP that's a lot more charming and fun. The gameplay's nothing special but overall it's a good time and worth it at sale price.

This is why I love video games. It's as far away from soulless AAA shooters as a game can get. Lovely scenario, brilliant writing and simple, yet engaging gameplay. If you don't like this game, there's a good chance you don't have a heart or your last name is Kotick!

This is what game design is all about. Basic RPG elements and turn based combat mechanics mixed with childlike imagination is the recipe for a maximum amount of fun. I'll be playing this game around many Halloween's to come.
If you're expecting an enthralling epic, don't look here. It's fun, it's simple, and it's reasonably amusing.
So cute and funny! Every new costume is exciting and you'll probably end up wanting for more. =)

I really love this game. It's cute and quite addicting. The combat is simple, yet sometimes I have to repeat a match quite some time cus I mess up on the combat/dodge. It's definately worth the money especially since I got it when CQ1&2 bundle was on sale for $1.99. Can't go wrong with that!

Probably the cutest game Double Fine has ever made, with a fantastic premise and decent execution. It's short but the length is nice for what it is, there are numerous laugh-out-loud moments with the dialogue, the environments are detailed and look quite nice, and the plot, while simple, is pretty enjoyable. That game is very easy in terms of its turn-based battles, so if you're looking for a challenge, look somewhere else. I do think it works very well as an 'introductory RPG', though, and can be used to teach newcomers to the genre about basic RPG tactics like prioritizing enemies, diversifying your party's classes, making strategic decisions about abilities, and choosing when to use special moves so they will be most effective. A solid game that makes for a fun Halloween night.

A clear love letter to JRPG masterpieces of the past (console) generations, mixed with a pinch of Double Fine's weirdness and a great sense of humor. If games like Earthbound the Persona series are on your personal all-time favorite lists you'd be doing yourself a massive disservice in passing up this title.

So, I'd like to say I've been putting off buying this game for ages. Literally, ages. What happened was with the recent summer sale in June, I bought the bundle of both games for 6$. Heres what I have to say,  ++ GREAT humor and storyline, ('Gus from section 5, your wife is worried SICK.' and the kid in a banana suit who said, 'This is a total banana-fest'. LOL. ++ really lovely backgrounds,  ++also you get to choose if you wanna be a girl or boy, which was not what I was expecting when I saw 'your sister does this' and etc.,  The game itself is really short which is a bummer to me. It has four levels, but they're all long in their own way. You have to trick or treat and solve an issue in each level, and you can play hide-and-seek (well its optional actually), and they'll upgrade your trick or treat bags to cuter and cooler things, you can make optional costumes in the game which can have a big effect on your battle; (I'm not a battling kind of person, but this game was fun and cute.) Battle stamps are the best.  The Grubbin's on Ice was really interesting too, its an add on to the game's ending.  I just feel sad its a bit short for me. Just a bit over 8 hours and I've finished it with all with all achivements to boot with no guide. You shouldn't need a guide for this game! It's fun and good like that!

Gotta thank one of my besties, gogostar, for getting me this game. Because of it, I love Double Fine Productions and will definitely be keeping an eye out for future projects. It's supposed to be a children's turn-based RPG but only informed teens and adults would understand some of the more subtle humor. I couldn't help but be reminded of The Nightmare Before Christmas (you even get to battle as a Jack Skellington-like pumpkin) but less deranged. If you're looking for difficult, intricate gameplay, this isn't your game. It's got a lot of charm, funny dialogue, good feels, nice art style, and it's adorable as ♥♥♥♥. What other game would let you duke it out as a vampire, unicorn, and a pirate (my favorite in-game trio)? Definitely recommended for anyone who wants to relax with a nice, cute story about sibling bonding and friendship.

It's a children's game. I got bored with it very quickly, despite the art style, background music and animations (which are all done well). Combat is turn-based, and consists of attacking and defending. It's a very very simple turn-based RPG. You have quests, you have an item slot and you can level-up but it's all so very shallow. Would not recommend for anyone over the age of 15.

I highly recommend this as a childrens game. It plays like a really simple stripped down JRPG, just set around halloween instead of around the coming of the great big evil that wipes out the world. You pick up party members, extra outfits that change play style, and it's a nice simple story with some half-decent mini-games. If you've already gotten a few RPGs under your belt you'll likely be bored out of your mind, but as I said a great 'my first JPRG' for kids around 8-12 yrs old.
great animations, and fun, until it gets repetitive, still good though 7/10

This is a very good game, the only drawback to me is that it doesn't have portuguese subtitles, so my kids can't play in my absence.

Loved the Game! Was super fun to while away the hours (not very many, but eh) and enjoy completing to 100%. I really appreciate that there are ways to go back to find things you missed the first time around. Can't wait for the 2nd one.

If you want a game that will get you into a Halloween mood, any day of the year, go for Costume Quest. Very standard RPG battle system, with a very fun story. Then, wait a few months and play Grubbins on Ice for Christmas!

you play as children going around knocking on doors and trying to find candy. treat its free candy. trick its a monster and a fight. The combat system is fun at first, but gets tedious fast. A real gem, Double Fine Productions does it again. 9.5/10

If you would have asked me if it was possible to turn trick-or-treating into a fun video game, I would have laughed. But after playing Costume Quest, I'm simply left in awe. It is so clever, witty, and charming--a perfect game for kids or just the kid in you. The look, feel and gameplay is somewhat similar to On the Rain-slick Precipice of Darkness. There's a lot of thought that went into the costumes, quests, battle stamps, and the special attacks. I challenge all doubters to say they can't find an enjoyable game in here. Two thumbs up.

Costume Quest is a simple, short and not very challenging turn based rpg; so while the mechanics of the game may not be groundbreaking it does leave room for other areas to thrive. The positive aspects of the game are found in the writing and the art, both of which will bring you good feelings if you have pleasant memories of childhood and/or Halloween. Maximize your enjoyment with this one by playing it in the appropriate season.
it was pretty spooky
An awesomely cute and hilarious game :)

Such a charming game. The graphics are cute and, even though the gameplay is the same as pretty much all the other RPGs, it still feels refreshing. Why ? Because most of the battles are based on trick-or-treating. And the gear you can collect are Halloween costumes. It's a cool idea, I really enjoyed it. But it does get repetitive near the end (it's about 5 hours long); the quests are the same in every new area. Apple bobbing, card collecting, finding hidden kids. It's a great game, but I just wish there was more variation. Still, if you love RPGs, or charming games in general, this is a must play.  [Rating: 86/100]
This game is perfect for gamers who like the fun and exitement this game brings. Its a silly game, But it takes a very long time to get through it.. :( Sorry but I dont recomend this game

Highly entertaining Halloween based adventure/RPG game. Turn based combat is simple to grasp and there is a good selection of costumes providing different bonuses and abilities during combat. Basic equipment system (Battle Stamps) allow for minor tweaking of your characters. Story is highly entertaining.
What more can I say, Costume Quest is a masterpiece. From story to gameplay Costume Quest lacks nothing.

I usually despise JRPGs, but I really enjoy the concept, story, characters, dialogue, and graphics of this game. The battles have enough for the player to do that make them better than typical JRPG battles. Basically, if you don't like JRPGs but are intrigued by the trailer and screenshots, this game might be worth a try.

Double Fine Productions (makers of Brütal Legend, and Psychonauts) have created another masterpiece in their latest game, Costume Quest. Costume Quest is a turn-based RPG by Double Fine. You play as a child on Halloween night in search of your twin sibling.  I’d recommend this game to everyone who’s mature enough to look at it for the first five minutes and dismiss it as a children’s game. The story, while well written is fairly predictable, and the grinding towards the end really detracts from the experience. [8/10]

This one was a surprise. When looking at some pictures, I wasn't expecting much, but was surprised by it. This game has what you can expect from Double Fine, very funny and well written dialogue, fun combat system and a nice world to explore. The biggest flaw of this game, is it's length and scope. It's a short game. But the 6-8 hours it will take you to complete it, will be fully enjoyed. The story, although quite simplistic, is fun and entertaining. The combat system is very nice, it's a JRPG turn based system with some quick time events thrown in between. When you enter battle, you'll transform into the costume you're wearing, so if you're using a cardboard robot costume, in battle you turn into a full laser shooting robot. The game has a lot of costumes and all of them very different from each other so you'll have to consider what costumes are best for each character and each situation. To add even more diversity, you have battle stamps to collect and use. These give some additional passive abilities, and make a lot of difference in combat. The game has a very simple level system and currency (candy). You can use candy to buy some upgrades and stamps to further develop your character. All in all, this is a very good bur short RPG, and I recommend it to everyone who likes the genre.

Where to even begin with this one... Costume Quest is something special. The setting is superb and the RPG elements are interwoven brilliantly. The dialogue is really fun to read and I found myself laughing aloud quite often. All of the costumes are really creative and super fun to play around with. This game just gets so many things right that you really owe it to yourself, especially if you enjoy RPGs, to play it.

I played CQ intitially on XBLA, and when it became part of a Humble Bundle, I had NO hesitiations grabbing it again.  A PERFECT game for Halloween, and worth EVERY PENNY of its full $10 price. That's why it's listed as #1 on my YT channel's list of 'Top 5 Games To Play On Halloween'.   Simultaneously spooky and delightful, and a ton of fun. BUY IT! :-)

Fun little budget title with lots of charm, but its nowhere near Psychonauts. Plays like a Paper Mario game with extremely simple rpg mechanics and timed button presses. It does get repetitive after a while but its not too long. Definitely worth $5 or so.
A very pretty game, I found it a bit slow paced and drifted off after a few hours, but I'll return to it one day.
A bit repetitive, but cute and fun for the short time it lasts.

Funny and charming. Really nice art style. Gameplay is pretty simple throughout but as the game itself isn't too long I never got bored. Really love the idea of the gameplay and characters being brought to life by these kids imaginations and their costumes. Just a sweet game, would recommend checking it out.
One of the best games that i played in my life. Alot of adventrues and fun.

Very nice short JRPG. The biggest minus is that it gets monotonic after sometime (the problem is that its only 5 [!!!] hour long). Buy it on promotion.
its GRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRREEEEEEEEEAT *thumbs up*

This is a really well-done game with a unique game mechanic, as you'd expect from Tim Schafer and Double Fine. They've clearly gone over the gameplay with a fine-toothed comb, and it's largely free of any serious annoyances (unlike, say, Psychonauts). I can't recommend this game enough.  After you finish the main game, make sure to play the included sequel, Grubbins on Ice, as well.

This is a game for kids, not kids-at-heart. I'm an adult, that likes Halloween. I like dressing up in costumes, and both handing out and having candy. I try to host a Halloween party every year.  I got this game because I was hoping that there would be the same level of dialouge and characters as in Psychonauts. It's not.  It's a very, very simplistic game, with choose a button and some QTE stuff. The costumes change things a bit, but anyone who has played any RPG type games at all can probably figure out the two damage dealers, one healer, or one tank, one damage, one healer, and not ever really need to switch costumes, besides to look at the different attacks.  It's not a bad game for kids at all. The writing is still decent, and some of the jokes were amusing, but as an adult fan of Doublefine who purchased it for myself, I feel let down. It's also a very short game. Again, one that would more appeal to a kid audience.  There IS a market for more adult-based Halloween costume style games out there that don't need horror or sex. I just wish Doublefine had realized that.

This is a really fantastic light RPG. It has that signature Double Fine dialog and in general the feel you expect from them. Just like I mentioned in my Stacking review this has reasonable achievements and very good accomodation for the completionist type. Appropriate since both this and Stacking was written in either 2 weeks or 4 weeks (I forgot the story) as part of a company creativity exercise.  It's really a shame that EA and LucasArts are such inept pieces of ♥♥♥♥ that they didn't capitalize on Double Fine during this period and allow them creative freedoms or the sequel to this would have came out much earlier and a Psychonauts sequel might actually exist. But oh well, great game overall and much of what I said about Stacking can be applied here. Double Fine knows you love to collect things and it knows that you love to 100% things, and they love you for loving those things and so accomodate you well.
If you are less then 10 years old this should be the perfect game for you, otherwise play something else...

The whole game concept/idea with the different halloween costumes and the fluid turn based combat system is great, nevertheless, this game fails in many other aspects.  Short game, beat it in 5.5 hours with all quests completed. Very easy battles. Missions are very repetitive. The story is lame and boring. The atmosphere is quite sad and dead, not much is going on around the different levels. Music and sound effects are poor.  I had higher expectations from this game.

Boring, repetetive, shallow.  this is what the game is in general.  you will fight the same monsters over and over again, you will use the exact same moves with the exact same characters over and over again you will do the same minigames over and over again   there is very little customization and most of it is just extra stats, no items, no unlocking new abilities. only unlocking new classes called 'costumes' once in a while and each costume has only 2 abilities.  the story is simplistic, the graphics are unimpersive, the kids look cute sometimes but that's about it.  this is 100% kids game. unless you are buying this game for your 10 year old naphew don't bother. it's a waste of time.  a big shame such a wonderful company like doublefine created such a shallow and generic title

I recommend this! For starters, its just so freaking adorable. The dialogue and the characters are so cute, haha. The game itself is pretty fun though. I haven't finished the game yet, but I'm quite enjoying myself. The fighting style is something sort of similar to Paper Mario in that you have to press the right button at the right time to use moves effectively. It's more fun that way, in my opinion. Also, you get to go trick-or-treating. I can relive my childhood every time I play, lol.  The concept is fun too. Being able to try different costumes is a cool idea, and watching them transform into incredible heroes is quite entertaining.   11/10 woot
Absolutely frakkin ADORABLE. The kid in you will love it for the costumes and cuteness, and the adult in you will love it for the tactical rpg gameplay. Lovely game, start to finish.
This game is very cute and fun! It always gets me into the Halloween spirit.
You can fight monsters as a Giant Cardboard Badass Robot ...or as a Fabulous Unicorn  no really. it's a really good game. If you like turn-based strategy games. you gotta check this out :)  10/10
This game is adorable. Regardless of one's age or gaming genre preference, this one is worth checking out, especially when it's available for under a couple bucks.
Very entertaining and fun to play.

I read the reviews and I understand that most people breezed through this game. That makes me hate this game more. I feel like ♥♥♥♥ now! Why? I simlpy SUCK at this pile of ♥♥♥♥ me off.
This game is cute as all heck and its by Double Fine. This is like a must buy.
A really charming short game. It's great to play around halloween, or if you really really like halloween.
The writing is sharp, the gameplay is excellent, and I will punch you in the ♥♥♥♥ if you don't play this game.

The mechanics are stellar, this game is practically perfect. I finished the entire game and got all the achievements but I'm so addicted I still crave for it. I can't wait for Costume Quest 2!  This game hooks you up right from the start, as you get more costumes and battlestamps the possibilities gets much deeper. For example, my favorite combination was the Statue of Liberty with splash damage, Vampire with additional damage and the Unicorn with health regen. You can heal the entire party with Lady Liberty and same for the Vampire but it's also a life steal. Then if either of them dies, the Unicorn can revive them. The Unicorn has high health and with the health regen, it is basically invincible.
Cute, quick little game. Little bit of strategy, a lot of great humor.

If I could title this review, it would be titled 'Fun Sized Fun' You and your twin are trick-or-treating on Halloween when a bunch of goblin-like creatures take your sibling because they can't tell between real candy and a kid wearing a costume. You have to trick or treat to get more candy and fight the creatures. The trick is that when you enter combat, whatever costume you're wearing gives you crazy powers. This isn't a particularly difficult game. I only died a couple of times throughout and that was because I made some boneheaded mistakes. The difficulty doesn't matter though: this is a clever, simple, fun bite-sized RPG that has a chewy nugget of heart at its center. It's a wonderful treat for the Halloween season (and the Holiday season with the included 'Grubbins on Ice' DLC).

Played this originally on the XBOX 360 and this year on Windows (I ended up using a gamepad since it just seemed more natural to me).   A charming little RPG for the holiday with some clever (alibet just text, no voice) dialogue.

The whole game takes place on Halloween night where you must rescue your twin brother (or sister, depending on who you choose) who has been kidnapped by candy-stealing monsters. You have to trick-or-treat at every lighted house to unlock other areas in the game world. If a monster opens a door you will engage in a random turn-based battle where your costume powers will come in handy.   On your quest you will meet other trick-or-treaters and pick up more followers for your search party. Collect candy from trash bags and smashed pumpkins which can be used to purchase perks in monster battles. Complete mini-quests to earn experience so you can level up. Do classic Halloween activities, like bob for apples and compete in a costume contest. Collect Creepy Treat trading cards and materials to unlock more costumes that have special abilities.  It's a unique blend of rpg-ing and casual gameplay that perfectly captures the spirit of Halloween. A must-have for those too old to trick-or-treat.

A game with all the charm.   Don't let it throw you off because of it's presentation, Costume Quest is actually a game for everyone. And a damn fun game at that. Fight casual RPG style while you kick candy stealing monsters out of your neighbourhood in awesome costumes you piece together on your quest.   With lots of little things that will make you laugh, charming moments that let you appreciate the game and enough of a game to leave you satisified when your done. Costume Quest is definately one of those games you have to play and experience.  I give it a must play 9 out 10.
If you suffer from yearly nostalgia around Halloween, but are too old to go trick-or-treating, this game is for you. The hilarious dialog and the fun visuals make this well worth the asking price.
Funny game from Tim Schafer. Behold: quick-time-event haters better stay off.
An awesome little game, full of humor and smart dialogue that provided me with a very enjoyable gaming experience. Would definately recommend picking this up.
Nice charm to it, but this game performs terribly. I can max out Dark Souls 2 and BioShock Infinite, but not this game? If the devs fixed this, I'd recommend, but not until then.

This game is such a little masterpiece... The cartoon-feel and cute characters gives it such a happy apperance. This game isn't very serious but it's perfect for someone looking for a quick playthough... I didn't notice a single bug in my short time on this game!...  If this goes on sale, grab it and enjoy!
One of the most adorable and addictive games I've played lately. It's hella cute, has a great sense of humour and is just a lot of fun.

This game is a tricky treat, in that the good, bad and ugly all relate to how  Costume Quest  definitely is not aimed at the 'core gamer'. If you spent tons of money on the latest gamer periphery, value your kill stats above all else and enjoy tons of gore - look elsewhere.  After all this story is about kids and seems fairly suitable for kids. In fact, I was thinking about giving this a Halloween run this year with a nephew of mine, but then realized one of the game's biggest shortcoming may be that it isn't voiced. That'll limit it's utility as a fun scary story for younger kids. Oh well.  The game features some pretty nifty concepts (such as Trick-or-Treating being basically a core game mechanic), offers a combat system that is modern (with various abilitites and quick time events), yet fairly accessible (casual gamers will get the hang right quick), and a scary-cute graphics style that really is key to making it work. Okay, the game isn't perfect (if some of the costumes have any use beyong unlocking that 21st achievement, I haven't stumble across it; they simply feel bad in combat), and is more adventure than RPG length.  Still.  Costume Quest  is well balanced for more casual gamers, has a very unique story and some nifty ideas. It may not quite be for 'core gamers', but beyond that, it's for everyone.

Trick or treating is now at your fingertips year round in Costume Quest! This absolutely adorable games leads you on an adventure to save your sibling from monsters. Collect gross treats, buy powerups with candy, and change out your team's costumes for special abilities.   However, there are faults. The game does get tediously repetitive after about an hour in. With about four different areas, you are performing the same side quests every time and battling similar monsters in a different arena. With the amount of constant battling, I wish combat would be a bit more interesting but unfortunately it just got painfully boring after a while and became a chore. The only redeeming factor of battles is the cutscenes when performing a special ability relative to the costumes your team is wearing. The design of costumes in battle was really well done and unique. Gaining new costumes to see in game was the only thing keeping me going after about 5 battles.   All the faults and boredom aside, it's still a cute and fun game that's definitely worth the sale price! I wouldn't buy it at its full price but it is festive fun nonetheless for all ages.

A good Halloween cartoon special takes me back to what it really was like - good, clean, spooky fun.   And this game makes me feel like a kid again. It's cute, it's decent and it's cool. I just wish it was longer.

A very fun, easy and charming RPG that takes place in Halloween.  You control as a few children going from door to door to get candy, or find candy anywhere in the area, to become more powerful in order level up and to unlock more costumes(abilities). The combat is very Final Fantasy like, and as you get into combat depending on what your costume is, you become that creature/character/thing, literally!   The game has the whole cute-ish estatic to it, while also giving you the feeling of the festive feeling of Halloween, which they succeed completely. The game is very imaginative, pretty good story, good controls and some pretty awesome fight animations.  The game is pretty short though, and the combat is too easy. Like, if you have a clear idea where your keyboard keys are, or even where X Y B A on your controller is clearly ( which most gamers do ), then you will have no problem with the whole fight at all. I wish there were difficulty settings so the game would be a little more challenging.  Nevertheless, good little fun game that would play again on Halloween.

Costume Quest is a game about capitalism and the futility of fighting the system. You play as Wren or Reynold, fraternal twins locked into a system in which happiness is always kept at arm's length. Your twin, the object of your worldly fulfillment, is taken from you, and you are forced to incorporate yourself into the capitalist consumer machine in order to free them from bondage - i.e. willfully enslaving yourself even deeper in order to cast off perceived oppression.   The erstwhile heroes are indoctrinated into consumerism through perceived need. Costumes and battle stamps are tools by which they can defeat their perceived oppressors, and candy and creepy treats are the currency by which they can obtain them. The creepy treats only award a special costume upon completing a full set, forcing the consumer-hero to seek out other members of their in-group to trade with and developing a reliance upon victimizing the out-group in order to obtain more. The same is true for candy, but on a much larger scale: widescale destruction and abuse of natural resources is encouraged, and upon reentering a zone the supply magically replenishes itself. Candy is ultimately spent on battle stamps, an entirely extraneous commodity that the game can be won without, but is marketed as invaluable and a means by which to constantly sink the children's personal supply of wealth.  The true capitalist hero of this story is Sadie, a brave young entrepeneur with a monopoly on the battle stamps market who is happy to aid the heroes in their fight against the villainous 'monsters.' She allows her customers to develop a dependence upon her product before beginning to dramatically ramp up the price to obtain newer and better versions of the same - designed obselescence at its finest. By the end of the game the player is lucky if they have several hundred pieces of candy in their bucket, while Sadie sits on thousands that the player spent to constantly upgrade their battle stamps. The 'monsters' of the game are cast as villains bent on hoarding all the world's candy for themselves, when in reality they are collecting it in order to save their own lives. Sadie, on the other hand, is motivated purely by profit - lying, expanding, and price-gouging to drive it ever higher.  The harsh reality is that this game is designed to indoctrinate the player into heedlessly reaping the world's resources and victimizing their competition in the name of achieving fulfillment. They are taught to at the same time fear and trust the two heads of the capitalist serpent, sybomically mirrored by the twin heads of the Doublefine logo: the Repugians, who are the face of foreign investments, and Sadie, the friendly face who is always there to help.   10/10 illuminati confirmed.

Costume Quest and it's sequel are colorful rpgs, with the usual mechanics. Press - here and such. However, they also have a sense of humor (And as always humor is subjective) The games are generally fun to play, the writing is funny, but there are a few reundancies in the script, as well as some sloppy writing. But that will only bother you a little (Or not at all if you're not a person particularly attached to grammar, and spelling. (I didn't notice any spelling issues)) The designs of the costumes, and of the in-fight character designs are pretty cool, though out of battle the costumes' design is more cute than anything else. The control scheme is a little difficult compared to console versions, but not so much so that it ruins the game. (Unless you have bad arthritis, than get a controller.) I got these games for a two for one sale for a dollar ninety-nine. Frankly, I think that this is terrible. These games aren't bargain bin garbage, they truly are worth playing.  Mechanics: Pretty much the usual, costumes offer new methods of traversal. -+  Graphics: Cartoony, but generally this improves the game. +  Story: Written with humor, and generally enjoyable. Although, there were times where the script could've been refined, I quite enjoyed the story as a whole. +  Gameplay: It was quite fun to play, maybe a little tedious if you can't find all of the houses, but this didn't bother me. + (That said this is the second game I ever fully completed, more commonly phrased as one hundred percenting)  Controls: A little difficult to use, compared to console versions, but this doesn't ruin the game. And you could always get a controller. -  Miscellaneous: The game was cute. But not overly cutesy, so you would have to punch a bear to get your manhood back after playing it.

I bought this game as it was made by the same group that helped with the Day of The Tentacle Reboot. Whether you should buy it or not kind of depends on what you're after. If you're wanting a mature in-depth game with vast arrays of landscapes, character development and difficulty this is NOT the game for you. This game is more of a kooky sweet family-friendly game to pass time with.  I'm a bit of a completionist and so I found this a fun simple game for completing the cute quests and unlocking the different outfits- it's not particularly difficult/complex but it can keep you engaged for a good 5-15 hours. I'd recommend it for when it's on sale at about $5-$10 as a cute game to whittle some time away with- but it's not something I'd want to pay $15+ for (as there are other more in-depth engaging titles for around that price instead).  People have complained that it involves childish jokes; however, to me it was no more childish than some of the original Dragon Quest games and so if you can put up with some of those jokes you can easily put up with (or even appreciate) these ones.  I found the premises of the game (go door knocking at houses, fight monsters, collect candy, unlock outfits to progress further through), unique enough. It is somewhat repetitive, however I feel that they've balanced this by making the game a short one with three parts taking place in three different areas. To me the game length is perfect - you wouldn't want it to be much longer as you'd get bored of the lack of variety but it has enough different elements to keep you entertained for the length of the game. I'm someone who really likes playing side-quests and mini-games so I appreciated the card collecting, bobbing for apples, finding the hidden children quests, etc they had. And I appreciated playing Grubbins on Ice as whilst you could see it was made off of the same kind of gameplay ideas it was different enough to keep my interest.  I thought the battle graphics were endearingly sweet- although it does involve turn based combat and unskippable animations which may frustrate some players. So- if family friendly games aren't your thing I'd recommend skipping this game. If you're after something short, sweet, unique and like mini-games then this might be the game for you.  But if you're really not sure if it's your kind of game maybe watch a bit of a playthrough or a few cut scenes on the community board. I did like this game, I would recommend it, but I'm also wanting to write this review so that those who wouldn't find it appealing can be more likely to leave it alone and not come here complaining about having 'wasted their money on a kids game'.
